data.title: Improvement: file explorer no scrolling by file close event
data.body: If I have many directories or files in file explorer, and I close a file that I'm editing, the file explorer will scroll, showing me the location of the next opened file, and that is many times displeasing. The file explorer should stay stopped until I will want to scroll it.

data.title: Add a queue for process.send
data.body: Fixes https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/13667

data.title: Editor save html takes longer after upgrade to 1.6.1
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Win 7 64bit

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Upgrade from 1.6 to 1.6.1
2. Enabled `"editor.formatOnSave": true,` 
3. When I try to save index.html with 2164 lines. It save after 2 minute or so. 
4. with this configuration `code  --disable-extensions .`

Sometimes when I try to do something it freezes.

data.title: Triggering find widget with the cursor on an empty line starts selection mode
data.body:
1. Put cursor on an empty line
2. <kbd>Ctrl F</kbd>

The find widget will search for a selection between the empty line and the previous line, failing to actually find occurrences in the whole document.

![bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22350/19388304/2580909e-921f-11e6-9b13-750df908bdad.gif)

data.title: Workspace setting not reading proxy values - self signed certificate
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.6.1 (9e4e44c19e393803e2b05fe2323cf4ed7e36880e, 2016-10-13T16:21:53.542Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601
- Extensions: johnpapa.Angular2-1.0.2

Steps to Reproduce:
1. New install of VS code, shift+ctrl+P type workspace setting, under setting set http.proxyStrictSSL: false and set http.proxy:"someproxy" then try installing a extension, getting self signed certificate issue
2. However moving the setting to user settings fixed the issue
3. also note I have already set HTTP_PROXY and HTTPS_PROXY set in user environment variable, which as per the documentation should also have worked

data.title: added "file nesting" support, based on file naming
data.body: Implemented "File Nesting" feature, which was requested by community #6328. Also created new 'explorer.fileNesting' setting and user can enable or disable it.

data.title: Loosing breakpoints when stepping in internal node module
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:
1. step into a node.js function (e.g. process.send)
2. set a breakpoint into the file close to where you are
3. continue stepping

=> I am loosing the breakpoint I had set when I step once

data.title: Debug hover and normal editor hover should align
data.body: Is there a reason we are still using the white background for the debug hover and the nicer style for the editor hover?

data.title: Debugging through readonly internal module has weird reveal behaviour
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:
1. debug into a node module (e.g. process.send)
2. step over the implementation in that file

=> each step results in the current line to be centerd vertically which makes it hard to follow the code flow
=> I would only expect the scrolling to reveal the current line if the line is out of view

data.title: stopOnEntry property not working when launching in node with babel
data.body:
I suspect this has to do with babel, however I don't see why it should stop it on entry.

[Image of bug #1 (transpiled code)](http://imgur.com/a/oBK6b)
[Image of bug #2](http://imgur.com/a/fLOCP)
- VSCode Version:

```
Version 1.6.1
Commit 9e4e44c19e393803e2b05fe2323cf4ed7e36880e
Date 2016-10-13T15:43:46.054Z
Shell 1.3.7
Renderer 52.0.2743.82
Node 6.5.0
```
- OS Version:

```
karl@karl-Dell-Precision-M3800:~/dev/node$ lsb_release -a
No LSB modules are available.
Distributor ID: elementary
Description:    elementary OS 0.4 Loki
Release:    0.4
Codename:   loki
```

It runs ontop of Ubuntu:

```
karl@karl-Dell-Precision-M3800:~/dev/node$ lsb_release -a -u
No LSB modules are available.
Distributor ID: Ubuntu
Description:    Ubuntu 16.04 LTS
Release:    16.04
Codename:   xenial
```

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Config files are as following (the code files aren't anything special):

launch.json:

```
{
    "version": "0.3.0",
    "configurations": [{
        "name": "Launch NPM dev",
        "type": "node",
        "request": "launch",
        "stopOnEntry": false,
        "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
        "runtimeExecutable": "npm",
        "windows": {
            "runtimeExecutable": "npm.cmd"
        },
        "runtimeArgs": [
            "run-script", "debug"
        ],
        "port": 5858
    }]
}
```

package.json:

```
{
  "name": "koa-babel-lasso",
  "version": "0.0.1",
  "description": "",
  "main": "./src/index.js",
  "scripts": {
    "bug": "node -r babel-register -r babel-polyfill --nolazy --debug-brk=5858 ./src/bug.js"
  },
  "author": "Karl Morrison",
  "dependencies": {
    "koa": "^2.0.0"
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "babel-polyfill": "^6.13.0",
    "babel-preset-es2015": "^6.14.0",
    "babel-preset-stage-3": "^6.11.0",
    "babel-register": "^6.14.0",
    "babel-runtime": "^6.11.6"
  }
}
```

bug.js:

```
'use strict';
import Koa from 'koa'; 
```

.babelrc:

```
{
    "presets": [
        "es2015",
        "stage-3"
    ]
}
```
1. 
   launch the debugger "Launch NPM dev"

data.title: Incorrect (potentially) indentation of function arguments spanning multiple lines
Default message for "Hit Count" is confusing
data.body:
Todays default message for the 'Hit Count' is: "Break when expression equals the hit count". This is a bit confusing because it is not clear what 'expression' is meant if the user has entered the 'Hit Count'.

Ideally the UI should get this message from the debug adapter because the exact syntax of the condition depends on the backend. Since we do not yet have protocol for this, I suggest the rather vague message:
     "Break when hit count condition is met"

I would expect that I get an empty edit box when switching to 'Hit Count'.

data.title: ${fileBasename} with extension, any variable without extension?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Window 7

Hi,

When using cl.exe in VS Code for C++, without other specification the output program is automatically named as {fileNameWithoutExt}.exe. In current VS Code, we already have ${fileBasename} with extension and ${fileExtname} (the extension). Is it possible to add another variable without the extension?

Below is an example in my launch.json file.

``` json

{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "name": "C++ Launch (Windows)",
            "type": "cppvsdbg",
            "request": "launch",
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/${fileBasename}.exe",
            "args": [],
            "stopAtEntry": false,
            "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
            "environment": [],
            "externalConsole": false
        },
        {
            "name": "C++ Attach (Windows)",
            "type": "cppvsdbg",
            "request": "attach",
            "processId": "${command.pickProcess}"
        }
    ]
}

```

It doesn't work since the "program" property will end up with foo.cpp.exe

Many thanks!

data.title: Side bar and status bar flickers when Code window maximized
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.6.1 (9e4e44c19e393803e2b05fe2323cf4ed7e36880e, 2016-10-13T15:43:46.054Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-43-generic
- Extensions: DotJoshJohnson.xml-1.6.0, EditorConfig.EditorConfig-0.3.3, abusaidm.html-snippets-0.0.17, dbaeumer.vscode-eslint-1.0.8, donjayamanne.python-0.4.2, eg2.tslint-0.5.39, johnpapa.Angular2-1.0.2, ms-vscode.cpptools-0.9.2, ms-vscode.csharp-1.4.1, msjsdiag.debugger-for-chrome-1.2.0, rebornix.Ruby-0.9.0, robertohuertasm.vscode-icons-3.0.4

I'm on Ubuntu 64-bit 16.04 LTS with a multi-screen setup: VGA (22'') and DVI (27'') from a Lenovo x240. If the code window is maximized I get occasional flickering in the side bar and the status bar. This only happens when the VGA connected screen is active. Also in full screen (F11) or when the Code-window is not maximized the flickering does not seem to appear. Other programs are not affected by similar flickering either as it seems. I use the standard window manager for this version of Ubuntu. I did not have similar problems before today when I started to use the multi-screen setup.

Some hardware details
Intel Core i7-4600U CPU @ 2.10GHz  4 , 8GB Ram
Intel Haswell Mobile

I realize that this probably is related to other things than Code, but the manifestation of these problems could at least be noted. 

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Maximize window on a multi-screen setup
2. Observe occasional flickering

data.title: Add staging hunks in Git
data.body: SourceTree has this feature, would be great if VS Code had it also.

data.title: Fixed #13670
Save backup files to different folder
data.body:
One feature I used to love from Borland CodeWright was the ability to specify a folder where backup files would be saved.  It would take the entire path on the local disk to the current file and create that tree under a specified folder.

For example, if I'm working on `c:\apps\foo\bar.c` and I specified the backup folder to be `c:\backups` then  any file save of `bar.c` would place the previous version as `c:\backups\apps\foo\bar.c.bak`

Can be useful in situations where a working file tree is accidentally deleted, but also handy to keep the current working directory clean.
